questions.text: A 34-year-old male comes to the clinic with dull aching abdominal pain for 6 months. He has a past history of Reidel's thyroiditis and was positive for IgG4 diseases. Which of the following conditions is his medical history likely to be associated with?
questions.solution:
Riedel's thyroiditis is an IgG4 related disease. This patient presenting with abdominal pain with a documented history of IgG4 diseases is most likely to be associated with retroperitoneal fibrosis. 

IgG4 related disease is a group of disorders characterized by tissue infiltrates predominantly composed of IgG4 antibody-producing plasma cells and lymphocytes, fibrosis, obliterative phlebitis, and increased serum IgG4. It is predominantly seen in middle-aged men. The IgG4-Related disease spectrum includes:

  • Mikulicz syndrome 
  • Riedel thyroiditis
  • Idiopathic retroperitoneal fibrosis
  • Autoimmune pancreatitis
  • Inflammatory pseudotumors of the orbit, lungs, and kidney

Retroperitoneal fibrosis is an IgG4-related disease that presents with backache, low abdominal pain, lower limb edema, and hydronephrosis from ureteral involvement. It can also sometimes cause periaortic fibrosis and cause abdominal pain radiating to the flank. The disease is progressive but can be slowed down with the use of IV steroids.

questions.text: A 50-year-old man with a history of coronary artery disease (CAD) presents with complaints of recurrent postprandial abdominal pain associated with vomiting and diarrhea. Abdominal examination shows no tenderness or rigidity. What could be the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Postprandial abdominal pain in the background of CAD is suggestive of chronic mesenteric ischemia(CMI). The most common cause of chronic mesenteric ischemia is atherosclerotic disease.

The three classic symptoms pathognomonic of CMI are:

  • Postprandial pain (crampy periumbilical abdominal pain within 30 minutes of meals)
  • Food fear (foods that precipitate symptoms are avoided by the patient and unintentional weight loss can result)
  • Significant weight loss

CT angiogram demonstrates both the arterial lesion and the patterns of collateral blood flow.

Percutaneous transluminal angioplasty (PTA) and stenting have gained acceptance as the first line of therapy for mesenteric ischemia. 

Nutcracker syndrome refers to compression of the left renal vein, most commonly between the aorta and the superior mesenteric artery, with impaired blood outflow often accompanied by distention of the distal portion of the vein. Most commonly presents with hematuria, flank pain, and varicoceles.

questions.text: An elderly male with chronic abdominal pain due to constipation comes to the clinic with no defecation for a week. X-ray of the abdomen shows a widened rectum with a low-density soft tissue mass with multiple air fluid levels. Laboratory reports are insignificant. What is the next step in management?

choices.text: Urgent colonoscopy for suspected Ca rectum
Administer a pro-diarrhoeagenic agent and send home
Wait and watch for spontaeneous passage of stools

questions.solution:
This patient with a history of chronic abdominal pain secondary to constipation now presents with no defecation for 1 week. X-ray shows a distended rectum with soft tissue opacity. This should raise suspicion of a fecal impaction. Urgent manual disimpaction should be carried out in this case, as if left unresolved, it can lead to bowel obstruction and perforation. 

Constipation is a term used to refer to persistent difficulty in passing stools. While less than 3 bowel movements per week is the traditional definition of constipation, it is also used to describe difficulty in passage stools, incomplete evacuation or lower abdominal discomfort. 

Once the diagnosis is established, any organic causes should be ruled out such as bowel obstructions, cancers, volvulus etc. The first investigation is usually an abdominal X-ray which helps rule out any obstructions. Colonoscopies and CT scans can be done during subsequent follow-ups. 

In case of constipation with no underlying cause, the patient should be advised of lifestyle changes including a high-fiber diet, exercise, and stopping any drugs that might be causing constipation. If constipation is unrelenting, then the patient should be advised fibre supplements, or other agents like senna or docusates which aid in passing stools. In case of severe constipation verging on obstruction, manual disimpaction should be done to prevent bowel rupture.

Other options:

Option B: This patient's lab reports are normal with no history mentioned indication of weight loss or other features of cancer. This, combined with his history of constipation makes fecal impaction more likely. 

Options C and D: Administering a pro-diarrhoeagenic agent and to wait and watch for the spontaneous passage of stools would have been the next step in management if there was no evidence of frank faecal obstruction. The stool should be removed as soon as possible to prevent progression to perforation of the bowel.

questions.text: A 45-year-old alcoholic presents with complaints of recurring abdominal pain which has increased in intensity in recent months. The pain increases on eating and he has now developed an aversion to food. He also reports bulky stools that are hard to flush. His abdominal Xray appears as shown below. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario of chronic abdominal pain with a history of alcoholism and X-ray showing numerous calcifications in the pancreas is suggestive of chronic pancreatitis. This is also supported by the finding of bulky stools which indicates a lack of pancreatic lipases seen in chronic disease leading to impaired fat digestion and absorption.

Chronic pancreatitis is a progressive inflammatory disease in which there is an irreversible destruction of pancreatic tissue. It is more common in males, with a male: female ratio of 4:1.

The etiology of chronic pancreatitis and pancreatic exocrine insufficiency can be classified based on the TIGAR-O classification system:

  • Toxic-metabolic -alcohol, smoking, hypercalcemia, hyperlipidemia
  • Idiopathic
  • Genetic- PRSS1, CFTR, and SPINK1 genes
  • Autoimmune- autoimmune chronic pancreatitis, IgG4-related disease
  • Recurrent and severe acute pancreatitis
  • Obstructive- pancreas divisum, duct obstruction, malignancy

The diagnosis can be made using Rosemont criteria. It is based on endoscopic ultrasonographic (EUS) findings. It is explained in the pearl attached below. 

ERCP is the most sensitive radiologic test for the diagnosis of chronic pancreatitis.

Other options:

Option B: Gallstones present as colicky pain after food in the right upper quadrant. Additionally, bulky stools are not typically seen with this condition. 

Option C: Peptic ulcer disease, specifically a gastric ulcer can present similarly, however, there won't be bulky stools in that condition. 

Option D: A patient with renal calculi presents with complaints of severe left loin pain and burning micturition. 

Related Pearl: Clinical Features of Chronic Pancreatitis

Abdominal pain: most common symptom

  • Site:
    • If infectious foci are in the head of the pancreas, then epigastric and right subcostal pain is common;
    • If the infection is limited to the left side of the pancreas, left subcostal and back pain are seen.
  • Precipitated by food intake, thus weight loss is also seen.
  • Associated with nausea, vomiting

Exocrine insufficiency:

  • Precedes endocrine insufficiency
  • Correlates with morphological changes
  • Manifests with malabsorption symptoms: steatorrhea, diarrhea.
  • Manifests with signs and symptoms of fat-soluble vitamin deficiency, such as bleeding, osteopenia, and osteoporosis: Severe cases

Endocrine insufficiency: Diabetes mellitus

Related Pearl: Chronic pancreatitis and pancreatic exocrine insufficiency: TIGAR-O classification system

Toxic-metabolic

  • Alcoholic
  • Tobacco smoking
  • Hypercalcemia
  • Hyperlipidemia
  • Chronic renal failure
  • Medications—phenacetin abuse
  • Toxins—organotin compounds (e.g., dibutyltin dichloride, DBTC)

Idiopathic

  • Early onset
  • Late onset
  • Tropical

Genetic

  • Cationic trypsinogen (PRSS1)
  • Cystic fibrosis transmembrane conductance regulator gene (CFTR)
  • Calcium-sensing receptor (CASR)
  • Chymotrypsin C gene (CTRC)
  • Pancreatic secretory trypsin inhibitor gene (SPINK1)

Autoimmune

  • Type 1 autoimmune chronic pancreatitis
  • IgG4 systemic
  • Type 2 autoimmune chronic pancreatitis

Recurrent and severe acute pancreatitis

  • Postnecrotic (severe acute pancreatitis)
  • Recurrent acute pancreatitis
  • Vascular diseases/ischemia
  • Radiation-induced

Obstructive

  • Pancreas divisum
  • Duct obstruction (e.g., tumor)
  • Periampullary duodenal wall cysts
  • Posttraumatic pancreatic duct scars

Related Pearl: Rosemont’s criteria for the diagnosis of chronic pancreatitis

  Parenchymal features Ductal features
Major criteria Major A criteria:
  • Hyperechoic foci with post-acoustic shadowing
Major B criteria:
  • Honeycombing lobularity
 Major A criteria:
  • Main pancreatic duct calculi
Minor criteria
  • Hyperechoic, non-shadowing foci ≥3 mm in length and width
  • Lobularity including three or more noncontiguous lobules in the body or tail
  • Pancreatic cysts ≥2 mm in short axis
  • At least three strands*

   *Strands are defined as hyperechoic lines ≥3 mm in length seen in at least two different directions in the body or tail of the pancreas.
  • Irregular main pancreatic duct (MPD) contour
  • Dilated side branches+
  • Main pancreatic duct dilation (≥3.5 mm in the body or ≥1.5 mm in the tail)
  • Hyperechoic MPD margin >50% of the main pancreatic duct in the body and tail.

 +≥3 tubular anechoic structures, each one ≥1 mm in width, budding from MPD
  Diagnosis of Chronic Pancreatitis:
  • Consistent with chronic pancreatitis
    • 1 major A criterion + ≥3 minor criteria
    • 1 major A criterion + major B criterion
    • 2 major A criteria
  • Suggestive of chronic pancreatitis (requires imaging for confirmation)
    • 1 major A criterion + <3 minor criteria
    • 1 major B criterion + ≥3 minor criteria
    • ≥5 minor criteria
  • Indeterminate for chronic pancreatitis (requires imaging for confirmation)
    • 3-4 minor criteria in the absence of major criteria
    • Major B criterion + <3 minor criteria
  •  Normal
    • <3 minor criteria

questions.text: A male patient, aged 60 years comes to the clinic with complaints of chronic abdominal pain since 6 months. He has a past history of gout and a 30-pack-year smoking history. Examination shows a pulsatile mass in the abdomen. What is his likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient with a 30-pack-year history of smoking presenting with chronic abdominal pain with a pulsatile mass palpable in the abdomen most likely has a unruptured abdominal aneurysm. 

Abdominal aortic aneurysms are mostly asymptomatic and are detected as incidental findings on investigations for other complaints. Sometimes, they present with pain and pulsatile abdominal mass. Rupture of aneurysm presents with acute pain and hypotension.

Management of stable abdominal aortic aneurysms:

  • Statins- atherosclerosis is the most common pathology associated with abdominal aortic aneurysms. Hence, statins are prescribed to reduce the risk of cardiovascular events.
  • Asymptomatic aneurysms <5.5 cm in diameter- serial abdominal ultrasound to monitor the rate of expansion of the aneurysm.
  • Operative repair is indicated for:
    • Aneurysm of any size associated with symptoms
    • Rapidly growing aneurysms
    • Aneurysms ≥5.5 cm in diameter

Note: Medical management with beta-blockers though helps in BP control, it is not effective in reducing the rate of growth of abdominal aortic aneurysms.

The given image shows an unruptured abdominal aortic aneurysm on CT:

The image below shows a ruptured abdominal aortic aneurysm. 

Other options:
Option A: Psoas abscess occurs due to a collection of pus in the iliopsoas compartment. The compartment is retroperitoneal and hence, the abscess is also called a retroperitoneal abscess. Clinical presentation is with back pain, fever, and lassitude. The hip may be in fixed flexion or there may be pain on passive extension.

Option B: While a small bowel obstruction can present with pain and abdominal pain, the mass is not pulsatile, it corresponds to the pace of contraction of the intestines and can sometimes be seen as a visible mass. This patient's past history makes an aortic aneurysm more likely.

Option D: Acute mesenteric ischemia usually presents with severe, acute, abdominal pain that is out of proportion to the abdominal examination. There may also be nausea, vomiting, transient diarrhea, anorexia, and bloody stools. There may also be mild abdominal distension and hypoactive bowel sounds.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man presents with intermittent fever, lower abdominal pain, and increased frequency of micturition for the past 6 months. Urine appears pale and opalescent with the presence of red blood cells and pus cells. Urine culture showed no growth. A CT scan was done as shown. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and the X-ray showing putty kidney are suggestive of renal tuberculosis. The given image shows a homogenous and ground glass-like calcification of the kidney appearing like putty hence called putty kidney.

Renal TB is caused by the dissemination of the organism through the bloodstream and is thus always a secondary TB. There is either reinfection or reactivation of old TB.

Clinical features of renal TB:

  • More common in males
  • Increased frequency of micturition
  • Polyuria
  • Painful micturition with often haematuria.
  • Loin pain and suprapubic pain. Suprapubic pain is more common due to cystitis.
  • Tuberculous kidney is rarely palpable unless there is hydronephrosis or perinephric abscess.
  • Sterile pyuria- urine is pale and opalescent with the presence of pus cells without organisms in acid urine—abacterial aciduria (other causes: interstitial cystitis, chlamydia).

Genitourinary TB is a cause of sterile pyuria. Diagnosis is confirmed with a tuberculin test, or at least 3 consecutive early-morning specimens of urine are examined for acid-fast bacilli. They are stained with a Ziehl–Neelsen stain and subsequently cultured.

The most sensitive imaging modality in renal tuberculosis is CT urography/pyelography. NCCT is the preferred means of visualizing renal calcifications.

 Manifestations of renal TB as seen on CT are as follows:

  • Early: Papillary necrosis
  • Progressive:
    • Multifocal strictures
    • Generalized or focal hydronephrosis
    • Mural thickening and enhancement
    • Poorly enhancing renal parenchyma
  • End-stage:
    • Progressive hydronephrosis
    • Amorphous dystrophic calcification that involves the entire kidney - putty kidney

Treatment involves short-course therapy with antitubercular drugs like pyrazinamide, isoniazid, and rifampicin. Surgical management involves partial or total nephrectomy and reconstructive surgery (e.g. for ureteric strictures) and surgery to the bladder such as augmentation cystoplasty.

Other options:

Option A: Staghorn calculus (shown below) is found in urinary infections with proteus, pseudomonas, and staphylococcus usually, and is not a cause for sterile pyuria.

Option B: Myeloma kidney often presents with Bence-Jones proteinuria.

Option C: Nephrocalcinosis is the deposition of calcium (shown below) in the kidney parenchyma or tubules which is seen in hypercalcemia conditions like hyperparathyroidism.

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman comes with a chronic dull aching pain in the right upper quadrant. The imaging of the lesion is shown below. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given history of chronic dull aching pain in the right upper quadrant with the given CT image showing a hypervascular lesion in the liver with a central non-enhancing scar is suggestive of focal nodular hyperplasia (FNH). 

FNH is the second most common benign tumor of the liver after hemangioma. It is commonly seen in young women. It is believed to be a hyperplastic response to an anomalous artery. Patients are mostly asymptomatic and FNH is often an incidental finding. If symptoms are noted, vague abdominal pain is the most common symptom.

On histological examination, cords of hepatocytes are seen with atypical biliary epithelium scattered throughout. 

Contrast-enhanced CT is diagnostic for focal nodular hyperplasia (FNH). It appears as a well-circumscribed lesion with a central stellate scar containing a large artery branching out in a spoke-wheel pattern. It shows intense homogeneous enhancement in the arterial phase and it is isodense as compared to the background liver in the venous phase.

The contrast-enhanced CT image of focal nodular hyperplasia (FNH) is shown below.

Due to the presence of Kupffer cells, FNH appears as a hotspot on Tc 99m sulfur colloid scan.

These tumors do not have the risk of malignant transformation, therefore asymptomatic patients do not require treatment. Careful observation of symptomatic FNH with serial imaging is reasonable, as symptoms may resolve in a significant number of cases. Patients with persistent symptomatic FNH or an enlarging mass should be considered for resection.

If diagnostic uncertainty exists, resection may be necessary for histologic confirmation.

Related Pearl: Liver tumors - commons

  • Most common tumor overall: Metastatic tumor
  • Most common primary benign tumor: Cavernous hemangioma
  • Most common primary malignant tumor: Hepatocellular carcinoma
  • Most common primary malignant liver tumor of early childhood: Hepatoblastoma
  • Most common tumor associated with arsenic / vinyl chloride: Angiosarcoma
  • Most common tumor associated with oral contraceptive / anabolic steroid: Hepatic adenoma
  • Most common tumor rupture spontaneously causing hemoperitoneum: Hepatic adenoma

questions.text: A patient presented with right upper quadrant abdominal pain that has lasted on and off for 3 months. Abdominal examination shows slight hepatomegaly. A CT scan of the abdomen shows a cystic cavity with a wavy linear opacity. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario with chronic abdominal pain of a patient with a CT showing a cystic cavity in the liver with serpentine linear membranes seen as wavy membranes within the cyst is suggestive of hydatid disease caused by Echinococcus.

Hydatid disease or echinococcosis is a zoonotic infection caused by the Echinococcus species of flatworms. Its life cycle consists of dogs as definitive hosts and humans as abberant intermediate hosts. Primary hydatid cysts most commonly occur in the liver. Most patients are asymptomatic but when symptomatic, the patient presents with hepatomegaly, pain, and obstructive jaundice.

The first/initial imaging test is USG, and a CT scan can be used to diagnose the condition. CT scan shows the presence of a space-occupying lesion with a smooth outline and septa. CT scan has an accuracy of 98% in the detection of hydatid cysts and high sensitivity to the detection of daughter cysts and extra-hepatic cysts. On CT imaging, the serpent sign is seen as wavy membranes within the cyst.

The USG of an active hydatid cyst shows multiple septations and a rosette or honeycomb appearance:

The ball of wool sign is seen on USG when the contents settle in the dependent portion of the cyst, as seen below:

On USG, the water-lily sign is seen in hydatid infections when there is detachment of the endocyst membrane, which results in floating membranes within the pericyst that mimic the appearance of a water lily.

Related Pearl: Indications and contraindications of puncture, aspiration, injection, and re-aspiration (PAIR) in hydatid cyst

Indications:

  • Relapse cyst, infected cyst, cyst >5 cm in different liver segments
  • Patients who refuse surgery or where surgery is contraindicated
  • Pregnant women, children < 3 years of age
  • WHO - type CE1 and type CE3a (transitional cyst)

Contraindications:

  • Cysts in lung
  • Cysts communicating with bile duct
  • Cysts with multiple septae—honeycomb cysts
  • Inaccessible cysts
  • Hyperechogenic cysts
  • Calcified cysts

questions.text: A 45-year-old male patient with a 20 pack year history of smoking comes with complaints of chronic abdominal pain, and early satiety. He has also had a 10kg weight loss in the last 3 months. Examination is positive for a succussion splash. What is the likely cause of his symptoms?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with complaints of chronic abdominal pain and early satiety with a history of significant weight loss. The presence of a succussion splash makes a gastric outlet obstruction the likely cause of his condition, likely secondary to a gastric carcinoma (significant weight loss and smoking history). 

Gastric outlet obstruction(GOO) can occur due to multiple etiologies including obstructions due to chronic peptic ulcer disease (fibrosis can cause GOO), motility disorders like diabetic gastroparesis and pyloric hypertrophy. It presents with symptoms of early satiety, chronic abdominal pain, nausea and vomiting.

Diagnosis: Clinical examination can show a visible wave of peristalsis against the closed pylorus. Apart from this, the patient also may have a positive succussion splash. This test is elicited by gently shaking the patient sideways and auscultating for a fluid splash. This test requires that the patient has not eaten or drank fluids in the last 3 hours. 

Plain Xrays can show air bubbles in the gastric area that do not cross the midline. Barium studies can be done to evaluate the exact site of obstruction. 

Management: 

Initially, conservative management is preferred if the cause is benign. This includes proton pump inhibitors, NSAID avoidance and evaluation for H pylori and eradication. 

If this fails, surgical management is done with endoscopic balloon dilatation. Stents can be used in patients who are not fit for surgery.

If the cause is malignant, then more aggressive management including gastric bypass after resection or palliative stent placement can be done.

questions.text:
Match the type of chronic abdominal pain with the likely diagnosis
1. Pain increases after meals a) Ovulation
2. Pain decreases after meals b)Gastric ulcer
3. Cylical pain c) Ovarian cyst
4. Diffuse abdominal pain d)Chronic pancreatitis
5. Radiating to the back e)Mesenteric atherosclerosis
6. Dull aching RLQ pain f) Duodenal ulcer
  g) Appendicitis
questions.solution:
The correct answer is option C 1-b, 2-f, 3-a, 4-e, 5-d, 6-c.

Diagnosis of many conditions can be aided by the pattern of abdominal pain.

Chronic pancreatitis causes abdominal pain that radiates to the back as it is a retroperitoneal organ. 

Peptic ulcer can cause variable pain, an ulcer in the gastric region can cause pain after food due to release of gastric acid, while duodenal pain causes reduced pain on eating since it leads to release of bile which can reduce the pain due to acid release in between meals. 

Ovulation causes pain in the middle of the cycle in some patients and is termed as Mittelschmerz.  

Diffuse abdominal pain is seen in mesenteric atherosclerosis. It is also termed angina of the abdomen and occurs due to a supply-demand mismatch leading to pain in the abdomen diffusely. It classically presents as pain out of proportion to the findings.

Dull pain in the RLQ can occur in right sided ovarian cysts which cause pain when the cyst causes a tractional force.

questions.text: A 25-year-old female presents with chronic cyclical abdominal pain. She also has pain during defecation and intercourse. Abdominal examination reveals no abnormalities, pelvic examination shows an immobile uterus. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient presenting with symptoms of chronic abdominal pain, pain during defecation, pain during sexual activity(dyspareunia), and with an immobile uterus most likely has endometriosis. 

Endometriosis is a condition that is characterized by the presence of endometrial tissue in ectopic sites such as:

  • Ovary (chocolate cysts- left/right lower quadrant pain)
  • Pouch of Douglas (pain during defecation)
  • Uterosacral ligaments (chronic pelvic pain & infertility)
  • Appendix (right lower quadrant pain)
  • Lower segment cesarean section (LSCS) scar endometriosis
  • Umbilicus
  • Lung (cyclical hemoptysis)
  • Vertebrae(Rare)

These extra-uterine sites of endometrial tissue are influenced by cyclical changes in the hormone levels which give rise to location-specific symptoms as mentioned above.

Management:

Investigations include:

  • USG: TVS will show a chocolate cyst.
  • MRI
  • CA-125 more than 35 U/mL
  • Laparoscopy: Gold standard for the diagnosis and treatment of endometriosis. It is used to locate the sites, take a biopsy and surgically remove the deposits.

Drugs used for symptom control include the following:

  • Oral contraceptive pills
  • Mirena IUD
  • GnRH analogs
  • Letrozole

Surgical management includes:

Minimally invasive surgery may be used to destroy the tissue by cautery, laser vaporization, and lyse adhesions that have formed as a complication of endometriosis.

Major surgical measures include incision of chocolate cyst and removal of lining, salpingo-oophorectomy, hysterectomy, and unilateral or bilateral salpingo-oophorectomy.

 

Related Pearl: Endometriosis

Sites of Endometriosis:

  • Pelvic endometriosis: Pelvic peritoneum, the pouch of Douglas, uterosacral ligament.
  • Rectovaginal endometriosis.
  • Ovarian endometriosis.
  • Chocolate cyst of the ovary.
  • Other sites—appendix, pelvic lymph nodes.
  • Metastatic— lungs, umbilicus, scar endometriosis.

One pathology review revealed that endometriosis has been identified on all organs except the spleen.

Examination findings in endometriosis:

  • Abdomen: Cystic swelling, fixed and tender.
  • Pelvis: Cystic tender mass.
  • Vaginal examination: Fixed, tender, retroverted uterus. Tenderness in the lateral fornices (indicative of endometriosis even if no mass).
    • Speculum inspection of the Posterior fornix: Bluish/blackish puckered spots on speculum, tender to touch. The presence of puckered spots is pathognomonic of endometriosis.
    • Posterior Fornix Palpation: Uterosacral ligaments & pouch of Douglas feel thickened and shotty with multiple small palpable nodules. This is called the cobblestone feel of uterosacral ligaments.

questions.text: A young woman presented with complaints of dysphagia, recurrent abdominal pain associated with nausea, feeling of 'hardness' over the left hypochondrium for the past 2 years. She reports that she is constantly worried about her symptoms. She has had multiple hospital visits, where detailed workups were not able to find any cause of her symptoms. She looks anxious with irritable affect. What could be the possible diagnosis?
questions.solution:
In the scenario, the presence of one or more somatic symptoms for more than 6 months in the absence of an organic cause is suggestive of somatic symptom disorder.

Somatic symptoms and related disorders group in DSM-5:

  • Somatic symptom disorder (somatoform disorder)
  • Illness anxiety disorder
  • Functional neurological symptom disorder (conversion disorder)
  • Factitious disorder (Munchausen syndrome)

Somatic symptom disorder is characterized by the fear of having a serious illness based on the person's misinterpretation of bodily symptoms. The symptoms are persistent for over 6 months.

It equally affects men and women and is commonly seen in the third decade of life. It is associated with poor insight. Patients believe that they have a serious disease that has not yet been detected and they can­not be persuaded otherwise. Their convictions persist despite negative laboratory results, the benign course of the alleged disease over time, and reassurances from doctors.

DSM-5 criteria for the diagnosis of somatic symptom disorder: 

  • One or more somatic symptoms that are distressing or result in significant disruption of daily life.
  • Excessive thoughts, feelings, or behaviors related to the somatic symptoms or associ­ated health concerns as manifested by at least one of the following:
    • Disproportionate and persistent thoughts about the seriousness of one’s symptoms.
    • Persistently high level of anxiety about health or symptoms.
    • Excessive time and energy are devoted to these symptoms or health concerns.
  • Although a single somatic symptom may not be continuously present, the state of be­ing symptomatic is persistent.
  • The belief cannot have the intensity of a delusion, as seen in a delusional disorder, and cannot be restricted to distress about appearance, as seen in a body dysmorphic disorder.

The disorder follows an episodic course separated by long qui­escent periods. Exacerbations of somatic symptoms are associated with psychosocial stressors.

Patients with somatic symptom disorder usually resist psychi­atric treatment. Management involves:

  • Group psychotherapy - provides social support and interaction, helping to reduce anxiety
  • Other psychotherapy - insight-ori­ented psychotherapy, behavior therapy, cognitive therapy, and hypnosis, may be useful
  • Regularly scheduled physical examinations - to reassure patients that they are being taken care of
  • Invasive diagnostic and therapeutic procedures should only be under­ taken, however, when objective evidence is present.
  • The clinician should refrain from treating equivocal or incidental physical examination findings.
  • Pharmacotherapy is used for treating somatic symptom disorder only when a patient has an underlying anxiety disorder or depressive disorder.

Other options:

Option A: Illness anxiety disorder deals with the fear of having a disease rather than a concern about many symptoms. Patients with illness anxiety disorder primarily concerned about being sick

Option B: Delusional disorder beliefs occur in schizo­phrenia and other psychotic disorders. They deal with bizarre, idiosyncratic delusions along with the presence of other psychotic symptoms.

Option C: Factitious disorder refers to the intentional falsification or inducement of symptoms with the goal to assume the sick role.

questions.text:
Following shows secondary features in patients with chronic abdominal pain. Match the symptoms with the likely diagnosis.
Symptoms Diagnosis
1. Hematuria, foot drop i. Carcinoid syndrome
2. Constipation, foot drop ii. Polyarteritits nodosa 
3. Chronic bloody diarrhea, weight loss iii. Ulcerative colitis
4. Chronic diarrhea, facial flushing iv. Lead poisoning
questions.solution:
Polyarteritis nodosa (PAN) is a systemic vasculitis affecting the small to medium-sized arteries. PAN characteristically involves the renal and visceral vessels and spares the pulmonary vasculature. PAN is usually seen in young adults with long symptom-free intervals. It classically presents as rapidly accelerating hypertension, abdominal pain, episodic bloody stools, diffuse myalgias, and motor peripheral neuropathy.

Chronic lead poisoning also referred to as plumbism or saturnism occurs following inhalation of lead dust or vapors that arise as a result of burning of paints, batteries, smouldering, glass blowing, and polishing. Chronic lead poisoning presents with colicky abdominal pain and constipation, in addition to neurologic deficits like foot drops and wrist drops. 

Symptoms of ulcerative colitis can include bloody diarrhea, abdominal pain, weight loss, fatigue, nausea, and vomiting. Ulcerative colitis is diagnosed by colonoscopy and biopsy: Crypt abscesses and ulcers are seen with involvement limited to mucosa and submucosa only. Pseudopolyps may be seen in chronic disease.

Carcinoid syndrome is a systemic disorder characterized by diarrhea, skin rashes, bronchospasm, tumors in the gastrointestinal tract, flushing, and cyanosis. The pathogenesis is mediated by components like serotonin (5-hydroxytryptamine), bradykinin, tachykinin, histamine, and prostaglandins.

questions.text: A 47-year-old male body builder presents with chronic abdominal pain. On examination, you notice a mass between the umbilicus and the xiphoid. The patients pain increases when he lies down. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of chronic abdominal pain with a mass present between the xiphoid process and the umbilicus makes an epigastric hernia the likely diagnosis.

Epigastric hernias arise due to chronic force like lifting weights or coughing on a congenitally weak linea alba. These patients present with a dull aching pain initially. The pain increases on lying on the back. The herniated mass is usually small, and there may be multiple discrete masses. The omentum and falciform ligament is present most commonly in the herniated mass. 

Diagnosis is via ultrasonography of the abdomen. Treatment is surgical to strengthen the linea alba and prevent recurrence.

questions.text: A 35-year-old man presents with weight loss and abdominal pain. He is a known case of celiac disease on a strict gluten-free diet. CT of the abdomen revealed a thickened loop of small bowel with stricture and associated lymphadenopathy. A lymphoid neoplasm is suspected. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The most probable diagnosis in this patient is enteropathy-associated T-cell lymphoma.

Individuals with celiac disease have a higher than normal rate of malignancy. The most common cancer associated with celiac disease is enteropathy-associated T-cell lymphoma. It is an aggressive lymphoma of intraepithelial T lymphocytes.

When the symptoms in a celiac disease patient deteriorate, even being on a strict gluten-free diet, cancer must be considered.

Note: Small intestinal adenocarcinoma is also more frequent in individuals with celiac disease.

questions.text: A patient with a history of consumption of snails and fish comes with chronic abdominal pain and jaundice. CA 19-9 levels are elevated in his blood. Which of the following conditions is typically associated with this presentation?
questions.solution:
This patient with complaints of chronic abdominal pain with jaundice a history of consumption of seafood and elevated CA 19-9 is typically associated with cholangiocarcinoma. He most likely had a Clonorchis sinensis infection. 

Clonorchis sinensis infection is endemic in South China, Japan, Korea, and Taiwan due to a long tradition of consuming raw freshwater fish or shellfish. Humans are infected by eating raw or undercooked fish containing encysted larvae (metacercariae). It is also associated with an increased risk of cholangiocarcinoma. In humans, it infects the common bile duct and gallbladder. Liver imaging shows a dilated biliary tract. It is a risk factor for cholangiocarcinoma. 

Cholangiocellular carcinomas (CCCs) or cholangiocarcinomas are mucin-producing adenocarcinomas of the biliary duct system that may originate in the liver and extrahepatic bile ducts. Cholangiocarcinomas are encountered in three anatomic regions:

  • Intrahepatic
  • Hilar (65%) - also known as Klatskin tumours
  • Peripheral (30%)

The sclerosing variant of cholangiocarcinoma is the most common and difficult to treat. The nodular variant is usually intrahepatic and presents as a mass lesion. The papillary variant is rare and is associated with favorable outcomes.

Portoenterostomy is done for hilar cholangiocarcinoma and for peripheral cholangiocarcinoma, Whipple's surgery is done.

questions.text: A 45-year-old G3P3 female patient with a history of chronic episodic right upper quadrant pain is being evaluated. Her BMI is 27 kg/m2. Her USG shows a Wall-Echo-Shadow (WES) sign What is the likely cause of her chronic pain?
questions.solution:
This patient with risk factors for the formation of gallstones (Obese, multiparous indicating fertility, in her forties) most likely has cholelithiasis. Her episodic pain is likely to be due to biliary colic, which occurs due to gall bladder contractions against an impacted stone.

If the gall bladder gets inflamed due to the impacted stone, the condition is called acute calculous cholecystitis. Wall-echo-shadow (WES) sign in USG is produced due to a well-defined echogenic gall bladder wall (W), overlying the echoes (E) from gallstones, and prominent posterior acoustic shadowing (S) that is seen behind the stones. 

Acute calculous cholecystitis is usually due to the presence of gallstones that causes obstruction of the cystic duct leading to inflammation, distension, and edema of the gallbladder. Clinical features of acute calculous cholecystitis are:

  • Right upper quadrant pain
  • Fever
  • Positive Murphy's sign(right upper quadrant tenderness on palpation)
  • Leukocytosis

Diagnosis: An ultrasound scan is sensitive in acute cholecystitis and demonstrates a distended gallbladder with a thickened wall, pericholecystic fluid, the presence of gallstone, and the sonographic Murphy's sign. CT scan also demonstrates similar findings as in ultrasound. A Hepatobiliary Iminidiacetic Acid (HIDA) scan shows obstruction of the cystic duct which definitively diagnoses acute cholecystitis.  

Treatment:

The first-line treatment would be medical conservative management to subside the symptoms. The conservative management includes nil per mouth with intravenous fluid administration, and administration of analgesics and antibiotics.

questions.text: A 48-year-old man, who is a chronic alcoholic presented with abdominal pain and vomiting. He had similar episodes in the past along with steatorrhea, weight loss, and fatigue. Which of the following test has the highest sensitivity and specificity to diagnose it as chronic pancreatitis?
questions.solution:
The diagnostic test with the best sensitivity and specificity for chronic pancreatitis/pancreatic exocrine insufficiency is the hormone stimulation test using secretin.

The secretin test becomes abnormal when ≥60% of the pancreatic exocrine function has been lost. This usually correlates well with the onset of chronic abdominal pain. An abdominal CT scan is the initial modality of choice for diagnosing a case of suspected chronic pancreatitis.

Investigation of choice of acute pancreatitis is a CT abdomen.

questions.text: A 28-year old woman presented with a history of chronic abdominal pain, diarrhea, low-grade fever, weight loss, and fatigue. She underwent a colonoscopy which revealed the following finding.  Which of the following histological findings is characteristically seen in the underlying condition?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario along with the cobblestone appearance on colonoscopy is suggestive of Crohn's disease. The presence of non-caseating granulomas is characteristic of Crohn's disease, although it is not very common. Features like crypt abscesses, diffuse inflammatory infiltrate and pseudopyloric metaplasia are common to both Crohn's disease and ulcerative colitis.

Crohn's disease may occur in any area of the GI tract, but the most common sites involved at presentation are the terminal ileum, ileocecal valve, and cecum. It is associated with smoking.

 

 

Clinical features include:

  • Crampy abdominal pain that may be limited to the right lower quadrant in patients with the ileal disease. More extensive/severe disease will have features of abdominal obstruction
  • Intermittent and persistent diarrhoea: Fluid secretion/impaired absorption in the inflamed bowel, bile acid malabsorption, steatorrhea due to loos of bile salts, enteroenteric fistulas.
  • Fatigue
  • Fistulae and abscesses
  • Malabsorption

It mainly affects the ileum and colon. The rectum is often spared in Crohn's disease. Gross features include:

  • Transmural inflammation: Full-thickness inflammation involving all the layers of the bowel
  • Aphthous ulcers: Small, shallow ulcers surrounded by erythema
  • Longitudinal ulcers: Linear or serpiginous deep ulcers 
  • Skip lesions: Involvement of discontinuous segments of the bowel with intervening normal mucosa
  • Creeping fat
  • Cobblestone appearance: Deep, longitudinal ulcerations interlaced with intervening normal mucosa.
  • Fibrosis, adhesions and fistuale due to increased inflammation

Microscopically aphthoid ulcerations and focal crypt abscesses are the earliest lesions. Non-caseating granulomas can be found in all layers of the bowel, lymph nodes, mesentery, peritoneum, liver, and pancreas. Other histologic features of CD include submucosal or subserosal lymphoid aggregates, microscopic skip areas and pseudopyloric metaplasia

The image below shows transmural inflammation where inflammatory cells (neutrophils) extend from mucosa through submucosa, and to the muscularis thereby, infiltrating and damaging crypt epithelium. The normally straight and parallel crypts appear distorted. Non-caseating granulomas are seen.

 

The image given below shows cobblestone appearance as seen in Crohn's disease.

Perinuclear anti-neutrophil cytoplasmic antibodies (p-ANCA) are found in 75% of individuals with ulcerative colitis but only 11% of those with Crohn disease. In contrast, ulcerative colitis patients tend to lack antibodies to Saccharomyces cerevisiae, which are often present in those with Crohn disease.

Extraintestinal manifestations of Crohn disease include the following:

  • uveitis
  • migratory polyarthritis
  • sacroiliitis
  • ankylosing spondylitis
  • erythema nodosum
  • clubbing of the fingertips
  • primary sclerosing cholangitis (more frequent with ulcerative colitis)

Cutaneous granulomas form nodules are referred to as metastatic Crohn disease, a misnome, since there is no cancer.

questions.text: An adolescent male with recurrent abdominal pain was diagnosed with tropical chronic pancreatitis. All of the following statements are true regarding this condition except:

choices.text: Can be due to excess consumption of tapioca
Alcohol plays a role in the etiology
Dilatation of pancreatic ducts due to intraductal stones

questions.solution:
All of the above statements are true regarding tropical chronic pancreatitis except alcohol consumption plays a role in the etiology of tropical chronic pancreatitis. 

Tropical chronic pancreatitis

It usually affects the younger generation in poor socioeconomic strata. Cassava (tapioca) ingestion as a staple diet is implicated as a causative factor due to derivatives of cyanide which require sulfur-containing amino acids for detoxification. These amino acids are not present in lower socioeconomic or malnourished individuals. Alcohol consumption is not one of the etiologies of tropical chronic pancreatitis.

The pancreas appears firm and nodular macroscopically. The ducts are dilated. There is extensive periductal fibrosis associated with intraductal calcium carbonate stones of different sizes and shapes. These stones may resemble a staghorn. Microscopically, intralobular, interlobular, and periductal fibrosis are the predominant feature. 

There is a high incidence of pancreatic cancer in these patients. The patient usually has type 1 diabetes mellites (fibrocalculous pancreatic diabetes). 

Treatment:

Medical management is the mainstay of treatment. It involves exocrine pancreatic enzyme supplementation, insulin for diabetes mellitus, and the management of malnutrition. Surgery is indicated in intractable pain and in dilated ducts with stones. The procedure of choice is the removal of stones, with a side-to-side pancreaticojejunostomy to a Roux loop.

Related Pearl: Clinical Features of Chronic Pancreatitis

Abdominal pain: most common symptom

  • Site:
    • If infectious foci are in the head of the pancreas, then epigastric and right subcostal pain is common;
    • If the infection is limited to the left side of the pancreas, left subcostal and back pain are seen.
  • Precipitated by food intake, thus weight loss is also seen.
  • Associated with nausea, vomiting

Exocrine insufficiency:

  • Precedes endocrine insufficiency
  • Correlates with morphological changes
  • Manifests with malabsorption symptoms: steatorrhea, diarrhea.
  • Manifests with signs and symptoms of fat-soluble vitamin deficiency, such as bleeding, osteopenia, and osteoporosis: Severe cases

Endocrine insufficiency: Diabetes mellitus
